review.title: Stratified Labelings for Abstract Argumentation
review.abstract: We introduce stratified labelings as a novel semantical approach to abstract argumentation frameworks. Compared to standard labelings, stratified labelings provide a more fine-grained assessment of the controversiality of arguments using ranks instead of the usual labels in, out, and undecided. We relate the framework of stratified labelings to conditional logic and, in particular, to the System Z ranking functions.

sections.heading: 7 Further Works
sections.text: Although [KIS11] also examines the relationship between reasoning and ordinal conditional functions in general and system Z in particular, the methods used in this paper differ significantly from the approach presented here. In [KIS11], the arguments are constructed from rules, and the reasoning framework appropriately chosen there is DeLP [GS04]. In the present approach, arguments are atomic (i.e., possible worlds), and the reasoning semantics are abstract. Relations between system Z and reasoning could only be established in a few specific cases in [KIS11], while we have a general argumentative characterization of system Z. In [Wey12], Weydert defines so-called ranking models for abstract reasoning frames. He associates with each argument a kind of conditionality that symbolizes the premise and claim of the argument, and interprets attacks in relation to (generalized) ordinary conditional functions. While such functions are also the basis for defining the system Z, the contributions we make to most of our time studies are abstract.

sections.heading: 8 Summary and conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we presented preparatory work for a new semantic conception of abstract argumentation frameworks: stratified labels. We analyzed some general characteristics of our approach and compared it with ranking functions for conditional thinking and similar approaches from argumentation theory. The key difference between our approach of stratified labels and other graduated approaches to semantics is that we measure the controversy of arguments, not their strength.

metadata.abstractText: argumentation frameworks [Dun95] take a very simple view on argumentation as they do not presuppose any internal structure of an argument. Abstract argumentation frameworks only consider the interactions of arguments by means of an attack relation between arguments. Definition 1 (Abstract Argumentation Framework). An abstract argumentation framework AF is a tuple AF = (Arg,→) where Arg is a set of arguments and → is a relation →⊆ Arg × Arg. For two arguments A,B ∈ Arg the relation A → B means that argument A attacks argument B. Abstract argumentation frameworks can be concisely represented by directed graphs, where arguments are represented as nodes and edges model the attack relation. Example 1. Consider the abstract argumentation framework AF = (Arg,→) depicted in Figure 1. Here it is Arg = {A1,A2,A3,A4,A5} and →= {(A1,A2), (A2,A1), (A2,A3), (A3,A4), (A4,A5), (A5,A4), (A5,A3)}. Semantics are usually given to abstract argumentation frameworks by means of extensions [Dun95] or labelings [WC10].
